title: More complicated tests sometimes need to have things set up before you run the code you want to test. It is possible to do this in the test function itself, but then you end up with large test functions doing so much that it is difficult to tell where the setup stops and the test begins. You can also get a lot of duplicate setup code between your various test functions.

inline_content.Text: More complicated tests sometimes need to have things set up before you run the code you want to test. It is possible to do this in the test function itself, but then you end up with large test functions doing so much that it is difficult to tell where the setup stops and the test begins. You can also get a lot of duplicate setup code between your various test functions.

title:
# projectroot/tests/test_stuff.py
import pytest
from module import stuff

content_resolved.code:
# projectroot/tests/test_stuff.py
import pytest
from module import stuff

title:
def test_foo_updates():
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    assert 1 == my_stuff.foo
    my_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert my_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates():
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    assert 2 == my_stuff.bar
    my_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == my_stuff.bar

content_resolved.code:
def test_foo_updates():
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    assert 1 == my_stuff.foo
    my_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert my_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates():
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    assert 2 == my_stuff.bar
    my_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == my_stuff.bar

title: These are pretty simple examples, but if our
Stuff
c
object needed a lot more setup, it would get unwieldy. We see that there is some duplicated code between our test cases, so let’s refactor that into a separate function first.

inline_content.Text: These are pretty simple examples, but if our
object needed a lot more setup, it would get unwieldy. We see that there is some duplicated code between our test cases, so let’s refactor that into a separate function first.

title:
# projectroot/tests/test_stuff.py
import pytest
from module import stuff


def get_prepped_stuff():
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    return my_stuff


def test_foo_updates():
    my_stuff = get_prepped_stuff()
    assert 1 == my_stuff.foo
    my_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert my_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates():
    my_stuff = get_prepped_stuff()
    assert 2 == my_stuff.bar
    my_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == my_stuff.bar

content_resolved.code:
# projectroot/tests/test_stuff.py
import pytest
from module import stuff


def get_prepped_stuff():
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    return my_stuff


def test_foo_updates():
    my_stuff = get_prepped_stuff()
    assert 1 == my_stuff.foo
    my_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert my_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates():
    my_stuff = get_prepped_stuff()
    assert 2 == my_stuff.bar
    my_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == my_stuff.bar

title: This looks better but we still have the
my_stuff = get_prepped_stuff()
c
call cluttering up our test functions.

inline_content.Text: This looks better but we still have the
call cluttering up our test functions.

title: Fixtures are much more powerful and flexible versions of test setup functions. They can do a lot more than we’re leveraging here, but we’ll take it one step at a time.

inline_content.Text: Fixtures are much more powerful and flexible versions of test setup functions. They can do a lot more than we’re leveraging here, but we’ll take it one step at a time.

title: First we change
get_prepped_stuff
c
to a fixture called
prepped_stuff
c
. You want to name your fixtures with nouns rather than verbs because of how the fixtures will end up being used in the test functions themselves later. The
@pytest.fixture
c
indicates that this specific function should be handled as a fixture rather than a regular function.

inline_content.Text: . You want to name your fixtures with nouns rather than verbs because of how the fixtures will end up being used in the test functions themselves later. The
indicates that this specific function should be handled as a fixture rather than a regular function.

title: Now we should update the test functions so that they use the fixture. This is done by adding a parameter to their definition that exactly matches the fixture name. When py.test executes, it will run the fixture before running the test, then pass the return value of the fixture into the test function through that parameter. (Note that fixtures don’t
need
b
to return a value; they can do other setup things instead, like calling an external resource, arranging things on the filesystem, putting values in a database, whatever the tests need for setup)

inline_content.Text: Now we should update the test functions so that they use the fixture. This is done by adding a parameter to their definition that exactly matches the fixture name. When py.test executes, it will run the fixture before running the test, then pass the return value of the fixture into the test function through that parameter. (Note that fixtures don’t
to return a value; they can do other setup things instead, like calling an external resource, arranging things on the filesystem, putting values in a database, whatever the tests need for setup)

title:
def test_foo_updates(prepped_stuff):
    my_stuff = prepped_stuff
    assert 1 == my_stuff.foo
    my_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert my_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates(prepped_stuff):
    my_stuff = prepped_stuff
    assert 2 == my_stuff.bar
    my_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == my_stuff.bar

content_resolved.code:
def test_foo_updates(prepped_stuff):
    my_stuff = prepped_stuff
    assert 1 == my_stuff.foo
    my_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert my_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates(prepped_stuff):
    my_stuff = prepped_stuff
    assert 2 == my_stuff.bar
    my_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == my_stuff.bar

title: Now you can see why we named it with a noun. but the
my_stuff = prepped_stuff
c
line is pretty much useless, so let’s just use
prepped_stuff
c
directly instead.

inline_content.Text: Now you can see why we named it with a noun. but the
line is pretty much useless, so let’s just use

title:
def test_foo_updates(prepped_stuff):
    assert 1 == prepped_stuff.foo
    prepped_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert prepped_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates(prepped_stuff):
    assert 2 == prepped_stuff.bar
    prepped_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == prepped_stuff.bar

content_resolved.code:
def test_foo_updates(prepped_stuff):
    assert 1 == prepped_stuff.foo
    prepped_stuff.foo = 30000
    assert prepped_stuff.foo == 30000


def test_bar_updates(prepped_stuff):
    assert 2 == prepped_stuff.bar
    prepped_stuff.bar = 42
    assert 42 == prepped_stuff.bar

title: Now we’re using fixtures! We can go further by changing the scope of the fixture (so it only runs once per test module or test suite execution session instead of once per test function), building fixtures that use other fixtures, parametrizing the fixture (so that the fixture and all tests using that fixture are run multiple times, once for each parameter given to the fixture), fixtures that read values from the module that calls them… as mentioned earlier, fixtures have a lot more power and flexibility than a normal setup function.

inline_content.Text: Now we’re using fixtures! We can go further by changing the scope of the fixture (so it only runs once per test module or test suite execution session instead of once per test function), building fixtures that use other fixtures, parametrizing the fixture (so that the fixture and all tests using that fixture are run multiple times, once for each parameter given to the fixture), fixtures that read values from the module that calls them… as mentioned earlier, fixtures have a lot more power and flexibility than a normal setup function.

title: Cleaning up after the tests are done.

inline_content.Text: Cleaning up after the tests are done.

title: Let’s say our code has grown and our Stuff object now needs special clean up.

inline_content.Text: Let’s say our code has grown and our Stuff object now needs special clean up.

title: We could add some code to call the clean up at the bottom of every test function, but fixtures provide a better way to do this. If you add a function to the fixture and register it as a
finalizer
b

, the code in the finalizer function will get called after the test using the fixture is done. If the scope of the fixture is larger than a single function (like module or session), the finalizer will be executed after all the tests in scope are completed, so after the module is done running or at the end of the entire test running session.

inline_content.Text: We could add some code to call the clean up at the bottom of every test function, but fixtures provide a better way to do this. If you add a function to the fixture and register it as a

, the code in the finalizer function will get called after the test using the fixture is done. If the scope of the fixture is larger than a single function (like module or session), the finalizer will be executed after all the tests in scope are completed, so after the module is done running or at the end of the entire test running session.

title:
@pytest.fixture
def prepped_stuff(request):  # we need to pass in the request to use finalizers
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    def fin():  # finalizer function
        # do all the cleanup here
        my_stuff.finish()
    request.addfinalizer(fin)  # register fin() as a finalizer
    # you can do more setup here if you really want to
    return my_stuff

content_resolved.code:
@pytest.fixture
def prepped_stuff(request):  # we need to pass in the request to use finalizers
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    def fin():  # finalizer function
        # do all the cleanup here
        my_stuff.finish()
    request.addfinalizer(fin)  # register fin() as a finalizer
    # you can do more setup here if you really want to
    return my_stuff

title: Using the finalizer function inside a function can be a bit hard to understand at first glance, especially when you have more complicated fixtures. You can instead use a
yield fixture
b
to do the same thing with a more human readable execution flow. The only real difference is that instead of using
return
c
we use a
yield
c
at the part of the fixture where the setup is done and control should go to a test function, then add all the cleanup code after the
yield
c
. We also decorate it as a
yield_fixture
c
so that py.test knows how to handle it.

inline_content.Text: Using the finalizer function inside a function can be a bit hard to understand at first glance, especially when you have more complicated fixtures. You can instead use a
to do the same thing with a more human readable execution flow. The only real difference is that instead of using
at the part of the fixture where the setup is done and control should go to a test function, then add all the cleanup code after the
. We also decorate it as a
so that py.test knows how to handle it.

title:
@pytest.yield_fixture
def prepped_stuff():  # it doesn't need request now!
    # do setup
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    # setup is done, pass control to the test functions
    yield my_stuff
    # do cleanup 
    my_stuff.finish()

content_resolved.code:
@pytest.yield_fixture
def prepped_stuff():  # it doesn't need request now!
    # do setup
    my_stuff = stuff.Stuff()
    my_stuff.prep()
    # setup is done, pass control to the test functions
    yield my_stuff
    # do cleanup 
    my_stuff.finish()

title: And that concludes the Intro to Test Fixtures!

inline_content.Text: And that concludes the Intro to Test Fixtures!
